resources.string: CONTACT (phassa): The word phassa comes from the verb phusati, meaning "to touch", but contact should not be understood as a simple physical effect of an object on the physical ability [touch]. Rather, it is a mental factor through which consciousness mentally "touches" an object that has just appeared, thereby initiating a whole cognitive event.
FUNCTION: the collision of consciousness and object.
MANIFESTATION: the coincidence of consciousness with sensory ability.
THE IMMEDIATE CAUSE: the object field that has come into focus.

FEELING (vedana): Feeling is the mental factor that the object feels, it is the emotional tone in which the object is experienced. The Pali word Vedana does not mean emotion (which is a complex phenomenon involving a set of accompanying mental factors), it is the most elementary emotional quality of experience, which can be pleasant, painful or neutral. \n While other mental factors outlive the object only indirectly, the feeling experiences it directly and completely. In this regard, other mental factors they are compared to the cook who prepares a dish for the king and only tastes it during cooking, while the feeling is compared to the king himself, who enjoys this food as much as he wants.
FUNCTION: experiencing, or enjoying the desired object directly.
PERCEPTION (saññā): His mode of action is comparable to the carpenterёs recognition of certain types of wood by means of marks placed [earlier] on each of them.
CHARACTERISTIC: distinguishing the qualities of an object.
FUNCTION: recognition of what was perceived earlier.
MANIFESTATION: interpretation of an object through previously perceived features.
IMMEDIATE CAUSE: the object as it appears to perception.

WOLITION (chetanā): Chetanā - from the same root as and citta, is a mental factor that deals with the actualization of the goal, that is, with the voluntary or volitional aspect of cognition. Therefore it is translated as “will.” The comments explain that chetana organizes the associated mental factors in the process of their influence on the object. As the main student repeats your own lesson and also forces other students repeat their lessons, and the will, starting to work in relation to its object, also forces the associated mental states to perform their own tasks. Volition is the most important mental factor in the generation of kamma, since it is volition that determines ethical quality of action.

ONE-DIRECTIONALITY (ekaggatā): This is unification mind on the object. Although this factor reaches its expressiveness only in the jhanas, where it functions as a factor jhānas, the Abhidhamma teaches that the germ of this ability to mental unification is present in all types of consciousness, even the most rudimentary. In them it functions as the factor which fixes the mind on the object.
FUNCTION: collect, or combine, associated states.

JIVITINRIYA: There are two types of control life-faculties: mental, which animates associated mental states, and physical, which animates material phenomena. But as cetasika This means only the mental life-controlling ability.
FUNCTION: to cause associated mental states to occur.
MANIFESTATION: establishing the presence of associated mental states.
IMMEDIATE CAUSE: mental states that need to be maintained.

ATTENTION (manasikāra): this is mental the factor responsible for directing the mind towards an object, whereby the object becomes presented to the consciousness. Attention - how the ship`s rudder, which guides it to its destination, or like a charioteer who sends well-trained horses (i.e. associated states) towards their destination (object). Mental factor manasikāra must be distinguished from vitakka: at that time how manasikāra directs the accompanying mental factors to an object, Vittaka applies them to the object. Manasikāra is an obligatory cognitive factor, present in all states of consciousness; vitakka - special alised factor that is not mandatory for process of cognition.
CHARACTERISTICS: leading (sārana) of associated mental states towards an object.
FUNCTION: bind associated states to an object.
MANIFESTATION: manifests itself as a confrontation with the object.

The Pali word "chitta" comes from the verb root chiti - “to know, to know.” 
 Commentators define citta in three ways: as an agent, as an instrument and as an activity. As an agent, citta is that which cognizes the object (āramman am cinteti ti cittam). 
 As an instrument, citta is that by which the accompanying mental factors cognize the object (etena chintenti ti chittam). 
 As the activity of citta itself is nothing other than as a process of cognition of an object (chintanamattam chittam). 
 The third definition, given in terms of activity, is considered the most appropriate of them; that is, citta is fundamentally the activity, or process, of cognition, or knowledge, of an object. It is not an agent or a tool, having actual existence in itself, separate from activity or cognition. Definitions in terms of agent and instrument are proposed to refute the misconception of those who believe that the permanent personality, or ego, is the agent and instrument of knowledge. Buddhist thinkers through These definitions indicate that it is not the personality that carries out the act of cognition, but citta, or consciousness. This citta is nothing more than an act of cognition, and this act is necessarily temporary, marked by emergence and disappearance. 
 While citta has the sole characteristic of knowing the object, a characteristic which remains the same in all its various manifestations, the Abhidhamma distinguishes different types of citta. These the types, also called cittas, number eighty-nine, or, if classified more closely, one hundred and twenty-one. What we usually think about as consciousness, is in fact a series of cittas - instantaneous acts of consciousness, occurring in such rapid succession that we are unable to notice the individual moments of their occurrence, belonging to different types. The Abhidhamma not only distinguishes these types of consciousness, but, more importantly, it also shows them in a certain ordered system, a single and closely intertwined whole.
FUNCTION: to be a “forerunner” (pubbangama) mental factors, in the sense that citta predominates above them and always accompanied by them.
MANIFESTATION: the way in which it appears to the experience of the meditator is it is a continuous connectedness of processes (sandhana).
IMMEDIATE CAUSE: mental-material (nāmarupa), because consciousness cannot arise one, in the complete absence of mental factors and material phenomena.

CHETASIKAS are mental phenomena that occur in direct connection with chitta, or consciousness, and will perform more specific tasks in the general act of cognition, thereby helping the chitta. Mental factors cannot arise without citta, just as citta cannot be completely separated from mental factors. But, despite the fact that functionally these two types of realities are independent, Chitta is considered as the main one because mental factors help in the knowledge of the object depending on citta, which is the main cognitive element. \n The relationship between the Citta and the Cetasikas is comparable to the relationship between a king and his retinue. Although they say: “The king is coming,” the king does not come alone, he always comes accompanied by his assistants. Likewise, whenever citta arises, it never arises alone, and always accompanied by his retinue - a cetasik.
